review_title: MSL - Do not join as a fresh grad
pros:
- Family oriented
- Nice colleagues 
- Good place to retire
cons:
- LOW salary. non competitive and far from market standard, minimum 30% below market rate
- Middle management are there for too long and cruising, no actual or relevant skill set. Limited capacity and capabilities. They are there to retire
- No development or mentorship, Too much legacy issue, no one will fight for your development and ideas 
- Poor digital infrastructures. Systems and software used are in the 90s
- Emphasis only for sales team. Middle office not given recognition 
- HR has the biggest say. Low pay, low increment, promotion base on vintage instead of capabilities. And HR are not doing proper market analysis on salary review. 
- Head office in MY has too much control over MSL for it to function effectively 
- MSL abides to HO and has little autonomy over business development
- No proper system and SOP in documentation and only do what is necessary when asked
- Because of the no retrenchment unspoken rule, there are a lot of people who worked in the bank for very long with irrelevant skills and are moving around different departments not contributing productively resulting in recent great resignation
- Fresh grad pay is less than $3k
- Drinking culture is prevalent, many promotions are base on relationships instead of actual work

Benefits such as mobile, but very low, many days of annual leave but not in comparison to other banks, there’s 2 weeks marriage leave as well if you’re getting married. 2 days of family care leave if not entitled to child care leave. Others such as flexi money, which is okay not substantial.
cons:
Terrible at staff retention, does not remunerate loyal staff with expected increments. Expects staff to take on higher positions and responsibilities for months before giving them official promotion. Lower management has poor skills in managing staff, systems all very backward, backend staff very unwilling to assist with change. Junior staff are paid more than senior due to “past experience” = age, which leads to junior staff not promoting even though they do the same amount of work. 

Medical not covered: part of flexi money which is a few hundred if you’re an executive. (Which is not comparable to industry (bank & FIs) standard)

review_title: Unfair & biased - driving hardworking staff & retaining useless slacking staff instead
pros:
Good colleagues (only young ones/class II help with the workload)
Benefits are good e.g. annual leave, marriage leave, family care leave, bonuses
cons:
LOTS of downsides.
Management is very biased and shows obvious favouritism -Unfair treatment to staff
Very poor staff management by dept head
No appreciation or recognition for hardworking and loyal staff
Usually staff who can work or do most of the work gets the scolding for minor mistakes but the useless slackers get away everytime (just bcos nobody notices them)
Systems, PCs and printers are all backdated and old
Lack of communication between class I and class II officers
Extremely difficult to get promoted or even pay raise
Basically, the bank treats lower class staff very badly. Low pay, high workload.

review_title: Good for retiring. lousy career prospect if you are young. not the place to stay if you want to do proper work and learn
pros: Salary and bonus is ok. You can get 3 months plus. The bad thing is that everyone gets the same and no one gets fired so there is no incentive to work harder
cons:
There is very little career advancement prospect. I have been working more than 10 years and never been promoted. They just released a memo where everyone is demoted because there are complaints of poor career advancement potential, supposedly after consulting some consultant. I am not sure what kind of logic is that. There are few trainings provided. The so-called HR lunch talks are a bunch of nonsense talks like How to Talk to Your Kids.

If you are in upper middle management, you can laze as no one gets fired. If you are a contract staff you get squeezed to death. nobody gets fired, so once they are confirmed, they can shake leg

pros:
good starting platform to learn the ropes if you're a fresh graduate. a lot of hands-on as a Relationship Manager. Depending the level of experience you have, you can come in as Financial executive, Wealth Manager, or Premier Wealth Manager.

Low turnover of staff
cons:
Slow to changes and slow to respond - i get exasperated working with their "speed" at times. sometimes you feel like they do not handle things with urgency... like a very laid-back culture. 
some departments cannot be bothered about the big picture and are isolated and like to play Tai-Chi sometimes by shirking responsibility. Low turnover of staff - usually means if your boss is staying put, there is little opportunity for you to be promoted too. Bosses are aware of the challenges staff faces but still wants us to take on a greater workload and expect us not to OT.

Staff turnover rate is high as well and yet the bank wants to reduce headcount. No room for career improvement.

review_title: Overall experience working in the CFS/Branch/Premier Centre/Sales
pros: If you focus more on benefits, Maybank is definitely a good option. Example, medical and dental coverage and it varies according to your job grade. As an RM in Maybank, it will be easy to build connections with various departments/branches/sales ppl within the bank and this should allow you to reach your targets for all your domains. If you are smart enough you can leverage on these connections for some extra dollars as well. When you hit your targets, the rewards are pretty decent. There will be additional campaigns throughout the year to help you boost your sales as well as let you get that extra moolah. And for top achievers, you will be sent on an overseas trip on top of financial rewards. Client database is huge. It is nearly impossible to run out of clients. It all depends on your skill of engaging with clients and eventually closing. As Maybank is an established bank, you have an extensive range of products, even those that don't fall under your targets, that you can offer to your clients. Thus, your client can keep coming back to you for various solutions. You will be a 1 stop solution center for your client's overall financial needs. In terms of resources to do your job, I would say it's pretty endless. The thing you probably need to worry about is competition from other financial institutions and sometimes your peers. Okay not sometimes.
cons: Personally, I would say the cons are a toxic work environment and this solely depends on the people in your team/office. I know of other Maybankers who absolutely enjoy going into office or if not at least had good colleagues/supportive Centre Manager. It was not rewarding enough for me. For the targets that you have to achieve and the number of domains you have to hit, it can get overwhelming. However, again this is different for everyone. Extremely competitive. No matter what, when it comes to doing your job, you need to be tough and rough in protecting your portfolio of clients and your sales pipelines. Be cautious who you share information with. If you under perform, you can expect to be drilled into the ground by higher management and this will affect your mental health. You are required to sell/achieve targets despite of market conditions. So be absolutely sure when choosing a career as a Relationship Manager.

- Salary is not negotiable even if you're mid career
- Toxic working environment if you don't get a proper branch
- Not easy for you to get promoted because there will be a lot of old staffs who's waiting to get promoted for years
- Not commission based job but more focused to yearly bonus
- No work life balance

review_title: Check Your Boss' Character before You Join.
pros:
The salary in sales is good. 
Benefits, 14.5 months pay. HMO - is ok but parents not included when single.
They have a car subsidy for M level and up.
cons:
Research on your boss. Don't just get the job for the salary. Boss is the most important. 
My boss did not have training on how to handle people because it is her first time. She acts like a child- make faces and make negative comments about others behind their back. She would only demand but would not guide you or tell you how to do it. She would blame you for not knowing. All she cares is her score and don't care about her team. She would not listen to suggestions as well. 

The worst is the weekend attendance on Viber of the nationwide sales team. Seriously? please respect personal time. OMG

Their training is awful and incomplete.

They hide the real status of the bank at the national level and keep reminding you that it's an international bank. They will not disclose who are the owners of the bank and the partner or conglomerates (if they have one)

Almost everyone in the company, especially in the higher management are new (less than a year). The old had been replaced or resigned for reasons that were never revealed.

pros:
1. Relatively easy to move between departments due to rapid bank development.
2. Relatively good remuneration compared to other local companies (Malaysia)
3. Business casual work attire (not much relevant nowdays due to Covid-19)
4. Offer working from home as an option for those who wish to work from home on fulltime
cons:
1. Slow career progression (most promotions are due to tenure not work performance)
2. Too much manual work (system upg cost prevented implementation of innovative solutions)
3. Hardware provided are unreliable due to low spec and old (the bank will provide laptops for certain positions which are relatively good in specs but due to all the security features it will drag the performance down. A higher spec is required). You can't use your own laptop to work.

5. Bad office politics as you climb up the ladder

review_title: In overall still the best in comparison of other banks
pros:
- wonderful benefits (medical is however capped a few years ago)
- gym facility at head office enhance work life and balance
- flexible working hour (remuneration may be revised if minimum working hours per week not met)
- working from home arrangement (remuneration may be revised if minimum working hours per week not met)
- numerous leave benefits (paternity/hajj/study etc)
- throughout career, have slept in office to meet deadline, pushed me to learn new formulas & processes to work things out faster
- fixed yearly pay increment depending on job grade
- Senior Management strive for improvement and positive change
cons:
- managers are not equipped with technical skills (Excel and other tools), unable to guide when in difficulties with process flow/simplifying things. unable to appreciate sacrifices made by low working levels
- managers are generally skilled in their field of expertise but most often unable to articulate well or in simple manner
- most email communications to stakeholders (not mass communication) & process working (excel) are usually already more than 5 years old without much attention to improve/simplify. Sadly, even though received feedbacks from stakeholders, no intention to improve if not instructed by own boss. Some of the staff prefer to push down the throat of the stakeholders that don't comply. 
- Most staff  and managers not willing to see new trends in providing effective communication or new formula to invent shorter ways in delivering results. Heavily holding the "play safe" card that curbs willingness to change to avoid mistakes and thus hindering creativity.
- very common to have seasoned staff (including decision makers) who prefer to remain until retirement and they would usually stick to old ways of doing things, not willing to change. many "too comfortable" staffs that even line manager unable to comprehend/manage. its a huge waste of money, time and talent.
- office environment so-so. depending in which department. in some, it can be very toxic/unhealthy. at times, its a particular staff who is causing the problem and in some cases, line manager unable to do anything because the staff is a senior and with most experience.

job_title: Customer Service Executive in Hong Kong
pros:
*Can explore new skills without any related experience previously 
*Many free stuffs at pantry which most banks did not have
cons:
*When I receive offer they promise me verbally that everyone of Maybank Hong Kong will receive 4-6 months of bonus so that they reduce my salary 20% from my salary bottom line but finally I receive nothing for bonus and I complaint to HR but it's useless
*They force me to resign at the last minute when my probation (9 months probation) is finish , otherwise they said will put me in bad record, it is because that they don't want pay me salary in lieu of notice
*When I attend the interview the job was about KYC but after I onboard I do nothing about KYC and I need to pick up all the task from the person which is going to leave in one week
*Since I no knowledge at other task and there wasn't enough proper training but the management blame on me and downgrade my year end performance report
*There's a big mess internally since turnover rate is extremely high
*Use crap banking systems , always have fault and error
*Management not professional at all and very to staffs (even swear to staffs)

pros: Great benefits, job security, decent salary n bonus, good learning opportunities
cons:
Its a place anyone in their late 30s onwards goes to retire. Management is very relaxed and half the time they don't really understand the segment they are tasked with. The sin is that they don't care enough to understand because jobs are very secure. For a young  driven person, working here can be very frustrating as this is not the place to push boundaries. Most people who have stayed with the bank more than 10 years are already in passenger mode. 

Career progression is slow without a senior manager to sponsor you. This is fairly standard in most organisations. What makes the bank worse is that you can be endorsed for progression at all levels and be denied simply due to age.

pros:
1.good bonus and benefit, full medical coverage, 30day leave after 5 yr, increments
2.great people, colleagues are nice intra department but most are rude when dealing with other department/center. 
3. Csr events are fun, try to join whenever possible (this is my only regret because I did not join them when I was there)
cons:
1. Incompetent boss/colleagues and increasing so. Expect heavy office politics and promotions are mostly for those who are close to the boss contributing to negative overall environment 
2. Stone age technology, almost no effort for process improvement although management will throw around big words like transformation etc.. No visible improvement at all, most recurring issue will be swept under the rug. 
3. Slow progression, as someone mentioned earlier this is for people who loves comfort zone and is afraid of challenge, you will be shocked to know how long has a person held on to the same position (their salary does not match job function as well due to increments). Training is done by hr only to meet their kpis

pros: Staff benefit. There is minimum of 20 words for this section. I cant find any additiinal.
cons:
-No OT pay, avg RM/h = former co. 
-Salary is so called above market value
-Work life balance is imaginary

review_title: Great benefits, career progression can stall though
pros: It's one of the main bank in the country and its goal to expand its market create interesting projects to work on. Other than that good medical benefits and coverage for families, work hours is mostly depended on the job, but quite a lot are 8 to 5pm with occasional overtimes and there are employee benefits for its products.
cons: Working in KL offices  though, commute can take up 2-3 hours per day.  Moving from one department to another for internal career progression can sometimes be difficult because current bosses has more authority on the decision to move. If he/she says no even though the other department wants you on the team, moving out is going to be tough. In addition, work can be moving a little bit slow, less urgency, long inefficient meetings ... But both issues (internal movement n urgency) are being addressed by the management somewhat.. thou it's going to take some time to change the culture.

review_title: Place to enjoy the perks but not the tasks
pros:
1. One of the best perks among company in Malaysia
2. Regular staff promotion for sunglasses, fragrances, stuffs
3. Good brand reputation
4. Regular staff activities and engagement encourage relationship-buildings.
cons:
1. Very slow career advancement - Maybank tend to hire people from outside to fill-in the vacant position.
2. Very boring work - repetitive, low-intellect, and monotonous
3. Highly political environments - Boss can have a favouritism
4. Perception issues - People in Maybank love to have negative perceptions towards anything new
5. Very difficult to work with old and seasoned Maybankers - they have a mindset of "I'm better than you since I've been work in this place longer than you"
6. Unforgiving boss if we didnt perform according to expectations
7. Average salary

pros: Depending on what you value on your work, me a good feedback and growth..hardly could see one & i can guess its very less depending on your Heads .
cons: lacks one 2 one, sub ordinate feedback and development discusiion, 5 years average for 1 promotion for officers which could be very much relevant if your doing back office Sales people could be faster entitled.

review_title: If u in sale get out!
pros: Good benefits compared to any other bank. Very good place to start your career (not sale)
cons: If u in sale then u better get out, the incentive is bad.. Im mean it IT's BAD..  If u are performer everybody will love u but the minute u fall they will throw u. Other departments im not so sure. No progression interm of career in sale line, they will tell u u have a bright future in this line but actually you don't, u will stuck at your same position untill dead.management won't trust u, u will not get any assistance (staff) to help u if you had a lot of things to do,this bank is more to operations oriented not business

pros: High benefit and the bragging rights that you’re working at the biggest bank in Malaysia. Great place to learn in regards to management
cons: Salary is half than what the developers from contractor agency received for the same amount of work and skill set. If you’re passionate about writing quality codes hence a polished software, you’ll probably need to look elsewhere as the main slogan here is, to deliver anything and everything as early as possible so that later the top management can brag that they were the first to introduce the technology to the market. A few months later you’ll be staying overnight just to debug what’s wrong with the code that you’re reluctant to commit.

review_title: Love and miss the place but how I wish.....
pros: Great environment, benefits and people at working levels.  Some people are so good at what they do, which to me personally, is an inspiration to have worked/known them. So humbly thankful for given the opportunity to have worked in the Bank. Many great talents around.
cons: Difficult to get internal transfers. Lopsided work load where some people are simply not doing enough work. Not been  appreciated for the work done. At times, over-bickering of small issues is seen which can be resolved with an open heart and mind. .

review_title: Worked with Maybank and its subsidaries, in various positions from year 2000 till 2013
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Kuala Lumpur
pros: Maybank group provided me a good opportunity to uplift both my knowedge and skills in the financial world. It also gave me personal growth in my career. It is a great place to work for those who thrive on team work and who look forward to a challenging working environment.
cons: Some times the need to excell in our given task, living up to the high expectations and continuously striving to meet challenges and date line puts you in a stress up situation. Thank fully the good support from superiors and team mates help to overcome the rough days.

review_title: HR was a nightmare, but colleagues are friendly
pros: Benefits are decent, colleagues are mostly friendly, although need to watch out for some with personal agendas. Probably the same everywhere.
cons: The head of the unit I joined promised me a certain salary. Hwen I went to HR to take the letter of offer, they cut down the number by a few thousand ringgit. Told me to take it or leave it. I though that was very unprofessional. Later found out that it had happened to at least 4 other people in the investment bank. I guess that must be the HR's modus operandi.

review_title: A stepping stone for fresh grads. Overall work-life balance would depend on your job function and who you report to.
pros:
- Largest local bank in Malaysia 
- Friendly environment in general 
- Good benefits
cons:
- Too large an organization resulting in job replication and slower career progression
- Conventional way of thinking and doing things making it hard to introduce changes 
- High bureaucracy resulting in slow turnaround time 
- Unspoken hierarchy that produces high power distance between management and staffs

review_title: A bank striving hard with backward mentalities
pros: The benefits of working in a bank and the 3.5% housing loan (after working for 2 hours) is great. The HQ has a great gym open from 6am till late.
cons:
Racial profiling is obvious.
Traditional paper base mindset with rules that change every other month. Training and development in IT is scarce, tho promises are made every year that things will be better. 
If you are handling a obsolete system i advice that you learn as much as you can on current technologies so you wont be left behind when you leave the bank.

pros:
Excellent monetary and non-monetary  benefits like performance based bonuses up to 6 months. ESOS, adhoc payments for festivities. Good medical benefits with good panel hospitals and annual executive checks.Medical benefits extended to immediate family members with unlimited cover.
Active in-house unions can negotiate good benefits extended to family members.  Good union-supported salary increments exceeding 10%. Many training programmes both inhouse, offsite and e-learning.  Bank support Govt Talentcorp.
cons:
Bureaucratic and redtape and cronyish do surface for promotional prospects. 
Heavy workloads with strict detailed KPIs to adhere to. Operations,Admin must also contribute to sales target.

pros: Company benefits are attarctive compare to other banks
cons: Politic is very strong, pusing responsibility when issue occured, back stapping to the higher mamangement, hard work being recognised my how strong is your relationship with the management, higher management only listed and take adivce from those employee that they like.

review_title: Good training and connections with others within the organisation.
pros:
Strong talent framework and training emphases.
Growing and advancing as an organisation.
Strong leadership at the senior to middle levels.
cons:
Promotion: Size of organisation means it may be difficult to advance quickly even if one is a top performer; if one doesn't have the necessary visibility with the Key Decision Makers.
Office Culture: Very relaxed and friendly; the people treat one another as a family more than most organisations I know of (though I have only seen first hand a few).

pros:
good medical benefit, work-life balance ok in some department.
too many events - waste of money and time..
learning opportunities is good.
cons:
slow career progression.
too many obsolete policies not updated.
too many IT projects that failed to meet expectations.
senior people hard to grasp the fast pace of technologies.
too many meetings..long-winded, dragging..wasting time and energy.

review_title: If you're a lackluster midcareer manager looking for a place to bunker down until retirement...
pros:
+ Serious attempts at upskilling people who are chosen based on recommendations by high level managers
+ Great health and related benefits that can't be matched in the industry
+ Maybank products can be innovative and exciting in the industry
+ Opportunities to transfer if you are one of the few recognised by a senior manager
cons:
+ All the upskilling in the world means nothing when you're constantly facing resistance to change from all levels
+ Salary is low compared to industry 
+ Managers who refuse to take responsibility or initiate meetings with the intention of delaying projects/decisions
+ Problems taken up with IR and HR are not always resolved due to internal "politics"
+ Gap between Head Office and branch's needs and requirements
+ There are many managers who are senior and close to retiring, but are out of touch and reluctantly do more than what is in their scope
+ Educating people on new products and policies is a huge challenge logistically 
+ Internal transfer is difficult and requesting one is enough to garner harassment from the supervisor

review_title: Maybank Legal - horrible place for a junior to mid level legal counsel
pros: HR Benefits such as leave entitlements and health benefits
cons: No career progression.  A revolving door for young to mid level lawyers. The same 4 senior legal counsels enjoy autonomy while picking on the junior legal counsels.  Prepare for many months of non-legal work such as organising fund raising events, roped into time consuming preparations for the annual dinner and constantly being saddled with time wasting tasks that the senior legal counsels do not want to do.  Like I said, hellish place for a junior to mid level lawyer.  You are better off working at an MNC or Int'l Bank or just going back to private practice.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Location- Park Avenue, trains close
Small office- good if you do not like very big size
New management is smart- I was hoping they could make some change
cons:
Too much office politics, very mean passive aggressive culture
Low pay, poor benefits
Easy to get stuck, difficult to move anywhere because standard is outdated. Many people have been looking for years but cannot move
Little teamwork, no trust
No training or mobility
Senior management get perks, but other staff very low pay and badly treated
Lot of discrimination. If speak Chinese that is bad. if not Chinese that is bad. Cannot win
Management does not care about rest of people in company

Have not had any so far. However, salary is generally a lot less than that paid by foreign banks. 
Very very less external trainings.

cons: in Indonesia, Maybank is not really well-known. And for those who really care about work-life balance, seeking to go home just in time by the end of working hour, forget this program.

pros:

However, after ex-CEO resigned in 2016 and replaced by new top management, all above 4 merits turned into totally opposite. The worst is (i) whole company just like the battle field of political struggle, (ii) no commitment by top management and overall power concentrate into certain meaningless departments like HR & Compliance
cons: No Cons actually, good luck to you if you decide to join it now

review_title: A great place to work for those looking work life balance
pros: For a big bank, the pace are much slower than the rest. The pay and benefit is good and is way above the average of other bank in the industries. Working condition is so-so depending on the department.

pros:
Good:
1. If you are planning to retire here
2. Still a very traditional balance sheet based bank - all other products, please stay clear
3. For department head roles who are good with politics. 
4. If you are Malaysia market focused
5. Depending on which department you are with, you can have a lot of work life balance  - IF you are in the right team -
cons:
Poor:
1. Strategy, where they are not benchmarking themselves correctly or just fail to recognize issues. 
2. Which leads to poor communication of goals and perhaps this is also due to..
3. Poor management that can't manage but yet are compensated well with the exception of the junior...
4. Compensation (typically 10 to 15% below market) and the bonus tries desperately to keep you in the company. After these years, its really not worth it at all. Its very difficult to leave the bank after being associated with it.
5. This leads to a poorer hiring pool and human capital
6. At the back of this is an ancient infrastructure as the group fears to invest
7. Perhaps too many cheerleaders and too little doers. Work life balance is celebrated but not practice - makes you wonder why are we being paid lesser than market.
8. Their risk and credit policies are a joke when you compare to regional players and doesn't reflect in their strategy
9. Negative environment, everyone hangs around just for the bonus but tries to do minimal
10. If you are coming in from a larger and more sophisticated bank, please stay clear, unless you are - please refer to pros -

review_title: A company with great benefits and culture
pros: A good place to work in IT field. Maybank always open its door for learning and polishing skills by sending us to training (and we can choose what training we want to go). Great benefit including medical, loans, leave. HR is up to date with current market trend. Promoting work life balance (including breastfeeding culture)
cons: Top management frequently change, thus impacting lower level directions.

pros: Company is part of Maybank Group giving lots of training opportunities. Engagements with internal staff are constant.
cons: Working unproductively beyond midnight on year round basis, with meetings starting at 11.00 p.m. several times a week. Indecisive leadership. Weak thought leadership. Uninspiring management and a tendency to sweep things under carpet. Loads of internal politics created by management to unhinge people who can really work and contribute. Cases of highly insecure leadership who use and then fire their middle management after objective is achieved.

review_title: Great to work in their retail sales team. I noticed office politics at play in other departments though.
pros: The people are warm and approachable. And if you're a performer, you will reap the benefits.
cons: Processes are either outdated or in the process of being updated. A lot of office politics in the middle and back offices. The international office has also started meddling in the Philippine office management.

pros: Benefits, the bonus, the company brand
cons:
Based on Group Compliance management and also the Hiring team:

1. They don't care about your work/life balance. Yes it's banking, and yes we are actually human being. Don't compare us (latest by 2 years tenure) with the seniors where they have to work till 12am because you guys don't have enough people back then! 
2. High expectations with a very, very low internal customer appreciations and no welfare whatsoever. Perfect examples are the ones located at Akademi Etiqa. The elevator, the toilets, the office itself, sometimes you have to deal with toilet smells in the morning, sometimes you'll get stuck in the lift for 30 mins or so, sometimes you have to stayback with no aircond on, no place for you to dine, no proper pantry, the microwave is placed next to the printer and shredding machine, etc. 
3. The higher management for team Mantas and eSTR is the worst nightmare. Mantas Head (no name mention), he's a dummy who just sits and listens but nothing is happening. He will repost what people sent to him via email but he doesn't really understand what's the content. Also the oldest TL in Mantas, is the worst of a person behind the scarf she wears. She's demotivating and heartless. Be very careful. While the Estr team, they basically just aim one group of people and talk bad about that group of people openly. One indian lady TL, she's the worst. She'd ask stupid questions about everything on a self explanatory matter. She creates hate.
4. HR is all over the place, one time you speak with this one, the next day is another. You have to explain again and again, and is it obvious they trying to avoid to do more work. No dedication, and no integrity. Out of 100, only 10 is reliable. I hope.
5. The system.
6. They just started with QA system hence their Checkers are with their own styles and if you're not in luck, you'll get the worst.
7. Ask you to do 10 alerts per day, but the system is out of date, not giving you to apply for OT when you stayback, they have done their so called motion study that maker can achieved 6 alerts per day in average. BUT that's it, they've gone back to 10 and no OT is provided for you to finish up the rest 4.
